original_title: Sri Lanka rupee volatility by banks covering positions, speculation
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The recent volatility in rupee has been driven by speculation and banks covering open positions on a Sri Lanka Development Bond exchange, Central Bank’s Director of Economic Research P K G Harischandra, said.
There are no severe depreciation pressures on the rupee from current account flows in the near term, he said.
“The recent changes in the exchange market was the Sri Lanka Development Bond related exposure of certain banks,” Harischandra told reporters.
“Now those uncertainties have been allayed to a great extent, bank are more comfortable.”
When the market panics and start reacting to some news, you will see some fluctuations.”
There were no major risks were seen remaining on the exposure he said.
After the domestic debt exchange and the overall debt restructuring is completed, conditions will become more normalized, he said.
The second half of the year would also see more inflows under an International Monetary Fund program, so there was less ‘justification” to expect large fluctuations going forward.
Under a ‘flexible exchange rate’ the central bank did not target a specific exchange rate, he said.
Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe has also warned not to regard the rupee “as a one way bet.”

Sri Lanka is operating an ad hoc exchange rate regime buying dollars and preventing appreciation amid deflationary open market operations (selling down the central bank’s Treasury bill stock which creates upward pressure on the rupee) but also staying away from intervening when some demand resumes.
The volatility of the rupee has also generally widened buying and selling spreads among banks.

Analysts had warned that Sri Lanka’s rupee tend to depreciate as soon as private credit recovers, as the central bank prints money to cut rates under flexible inflation targeting usually in the second year of an International Monetary Fund program. (Colombo/Aug04/2023)
